bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1949

div1.p: Moran informs Hench that he has decided not to publish his memoirs because he feels it would further antagonize Cuba. He offers his opinion on the political and cultural situation in Cuba, especially as it pertains to the preservation of Camp Lazear. Finally, he makes clear his position in the Reed-Finlay debate concerning credit for conquering yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1949
div1.opener:
JOHN J. MORAN
HAVANA, CUBA
February 5, 1949.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Colonel:
div1.p:
Since I wrote to you on October 9th and during your long
absence in Europe I hava had time and reason to reflect on the
wisdom of having “MY DATE WITH WALTER REED AND YELLOW JACK” edited
and published, as I planned to do, following destruction of the
manuscript I had written before my session with the Grim Reaper, in
September, 1947, and whom I temporarily cheated.

Now, I have arrived at a definite decision, a decision
which I will endeavor to justify to you, with my apologies, for the
time and trouble I have imposed upon you in a matter which has
involved vacillation and indecision on my part.

Since the one object I have had in mind has been that of
doing justice to the memory of Reed as against the all-out claims
of the Cubans for Finlay, I have reluctantly come to the conclusion
that publication of my memoirs would further antagonize, rather than
diminish, the well-known attitude of the Cubans in their unilateral
claims for Finlay.

You cannot convince a people with closed minds and whose
slogan is and has been that “To be a good Cuban you have to be anti-
American”. That spirit is congenital in the present generation of
Cubans, facts and logic playing no part in their way of thinking.
Less than three months ago, the slogan was reiterated by our mild-
mannered friend Dr. Emilio Roig de Leuchsenring, Historian of the
City of Havana, at a mass meeting in Central Park honoring the
deposed president of Venezuela, ousted by a military clique. You
will recall that Dr. E. R. de L. gave us autographed copies of his
“LA HABANA - Apuntes Historicas”. The overthrow of the Venezuelan
president was ascribed in part to Peron and in part to our State
Department. Yankee Imperialism is always sure to “bring down the
house” in every Latin American republic.

Following the well-known practice of the Cubans of condemn-
ing everything American which may run counter to their views, they
would be sure to crucify me if my memoirs were to be published in
the manner and language which I deem appropriate. I could not white-
wash the Cubans in any article or book to bear my name as author. I
would certainly call a spade a spade in dealing with the Finlay-Reed
controversy. Therefore, while I am the stranger in their midst, I
cannot afford to antagonize them. I am sure the State Department
would not look upon my memoirs as a service to my adopted country,
anxious as they are in Washington to play up the Good Neighbor policy.

I thought I knew the Cubans when I took up permanent residence
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 2 --
Feb. 5, 1949.
here in 1928, but I have learned better during those 20 years. They
are long on promises and short on performance, with a chip on their
shoulders which may be displaced temporarily, only to be replaced by
another without loss of time. Sure, like all Latin-Americans, they
are 100% for our Good Neighbor Policy and to which they contribute not-
hing. By the way that GNP is a false alarm, with Uncle Sam playing
the game of sucker.

The Cubans have been constantly reminding us of the sacrifices
they made during the recent World Conflict. What were those “sacri-
fices”? Selling us their sugar at prices they had never dreamed of
obtaining. Every mortgaged sugar plantation and sugar mill was able
to pay off their mortgages, pay handsome dividends and build up a
reserve. Let me here state a fact. There was not a financially sound
sugar plantation or mill on the Island when World War II started. All
except the American-owned sugar mills were bankrupt. And yet a lot of
Americans swallow that “sacrifice” propaganda. In fine, the Good-
Neighbor-Policy has been a Santa Claus for the Latin Americans, with
Cuba one of its most favored beneficiares.

With reference to the “caseta”. The charcoal vendor and his
wife roped it to nearby trees before the hurricane arrived. The Govern-
ment cared little what might happen to it. The $50,000 appropriated
for the “memorial” and situated by the Ministry of Finance “evaporated”
between the Treasury and Public Works. Presumably it forms a part of
the $174,000,000 illegally disposed of by President Grau San Martin and
his ministers during the four years ended October 10, 1948, now being
aired before the Supreme Court of Cuba, Criminal Section. Since loot-
ing of the public treasury has become an institution in Cuba, few of
the natives believe that Grau & Company will be found guilty or obliged
to restore their ill-gotten millions. They will continue to enjoy
their loot and will suffer no loss of their civil rights, nor will
they be ostracised by their fellows. Their social functions will be
attended by the elite and envied by those who cannot afford the luxury
of spending $10,000 to $50,000 on a banquet. Grau, of course, did
not, personally, steal any of the missing millions. His sister-in-law,
who acted as the First Lady of the Land, collected more than a fair
share of the spoils for both, she being a widow and he being a bachellor.

You will be arriving at the conclusion that I am too severe
on the Cubans. I am not judging them by my own code of morals but by
what I imagine your moral code is, a code that is common to most
decent and honorable Americans. You will be wondering why I have
continued to live among them since my retirement. The answer is simple.
I have spent so many years of my life away from God's Country, 20 of
them here in Havana, that to settle down in a temperate zone would
impose great hardship upon me. Also, here my wife has formed her own
limited circle and five of her brothers and sisters live in Havana.
She would miss Havana much more than I would. Plenty of good reading
material is sufficient company for me, plus radio and an occasional
bridge game. She, naturally, wants her circle of friends.

I am not destrying the memoirs I have prepared. If I should
survive Elida, the manuscript will be yours for whatever it may be worth.
If she survives me, it will be hers, to do with as she pleases. So far
as your own work on Yellow Fever is concerned, I can contribute nothing
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 3 --
Feb. 5, 1949.
which you do not already know from my voluminous correspondence with
you over a period of almost twelve years, to be exact, since July,
1937. How time flies when one has passed the half-century mark!

I have not forgotten your request for a photograph of my
Congressional Medal. I will go to the bank one of these days and
take it out to have it photographed, as per your instructions, on a
dark velvet or dark background. If I had had the medal in my house
you would have received the photograph long ago. So far as your other
unfinished business in Cuba is concerned, I hope Dr. Noguera will be
able to help you out. He can do much more than I can in the matter
of photostatic copies of newspaper articles which you are anxious to
add to your collection of data. He told me several months ago that
he could arrange to have the newspapers taken to the photographer,
a privilege which was denied me. Also, since you must still be
interested, he will be able to inform you as to the chances of having
the memorial at Camp Lazear revived under the present administration.
Do you have any recent letters from Dr. Nogueira in connection with
this project and with that of the photostats?

I hope you will have the patience to read this long-winded
letter, most of which is devoted to topics which can interest you
but little. In a way, it may prepare you for some of the unfavorable
comment which your History of Yellow Fever is sure to encounter at
the hands of the Cubans, regardless of how well Finlay may fare at
your hands. No matter how much you may laud Finlay, if you do justice
to Reed, you will be damned by the diehards here, and they are many.

I have not the slightest doubt that you will give Reed all
the credit to which his memory is entitled, which is more than could
be expected of me, in that I am prejudiced in his favor as opposed
to the Cuban claims for Finlay, an admission the existence of which
has been well known to you for many years. It would be hypocrisy on
my part to proclaim that I honor the memory of Finlay on a par with
that of Reed, although my memoirs claim an equal division of the
glory as between the two immortals. In doing that, I have certainly
been magnanimous to Finlay and his memory. Perhaps my lack of contact
with Finlay during the experiments carried out at Camp Lazear will
account for this discrepancy. To this day I cannot vision Finlay as
a Cuban. He was accidentally born here of European parents, but he
did not have a drop of Cuban or Spanish blood in his veins.

Well, allow me to draw this rambling letter to a close and
to cease torturing you with thoughts and sentiments which can be of
little interest to you. Pardon my effusions and ascribe some of
them to my 73 years, grey hairs and state of my health.

With love from Elida and myself to Mary, the youngsters and
yourself, I remain,
div1.closer:
Always your friend, John J. Moran Calle 25 No. 804,
(entre B y C)
Vedado, HAVANA, CUBA.
